Element Name: Coin, Vending, and Amusement Machine Servicers and Repairers
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Professionals in this field install, maintain, and repair various types of coin-operated and amusement machines. Their daily work involves inspecting equipment to identify operational issues, troubleshooting malfunctions, and performing necessary repairs. This often includes cleaning and oiling parts, replacing defective components, and testing machines to ensure they function correctly. They may also be responsible for stocking machines with products and supplies, and managing the money collected. Keeping detailed records of all maintenance and repair activities is a crucial part of their responsibilities, ensuring equipment longevity and proper operation. They utilize hand tools and technical diagrams to complete their repair tasks.

ONET description:
Install, service, adjust, or repair coin, vending, or amusement machines including video games, juke boxes, pinball machines, or slot machines.

Tasks:
[{'Task': 'Fill machines with products, ingredients, money, and other supplies.'}, {'Task': 'Inspect machines and meters to determine causes of malfunctions and fix minor problems such as jammed bills or stuck products.'}, {'Task': 'Test machines to determine proper functioning.'}, {'Task': 'Replace malfunctioning parts, such as worn magnetic heads on automatic teller machine (ATM) card readers.'}, {'Task': 'Maintain records of machine maintenance and repair.'}, {'Task': 'Clean and oil machine parts.'}, {'Task': 'Order parts needed for machine repairs.'}, {'Task': 'Adjust and repair coin, vending, or amusement machines and meters and replace defective mechanical and electrical parts, using hand tools, soldering irons, and diagrams.'}, {'Task': 'Record transaction information on forms or logs, and notify designated personnel of discrepancies.'}]

Generated description:
Individuals in this role prepare for underwater operations by checking and maintaining specialized breathing apparatus and safety equipment. They communicate with surface teams to receive instructions and report conditions. Once submerged, they perform a range of tasks including inspecting structures, repairing damages, and installing new components using various hand and power tools. This may involve cutting, welding, or rigging objects for retrieval. They also document their findings through photography or testing, and meticulously follow safety protocols to manage dive times and depths. Their work often includes recovery, salvage, or cleanup efforts, requiring careful decision-making in challenging environments.

ONET description:
Work below surface of water, using surface-supplied air or scuba equipment to inspect, repair, remove, or install equipment and structures. May use a variety of power and hand tools, such as drills, sledgehammers, torches, and welding equipment. May conduct tests or experiments, rig explosives, or photograph structures or marine life.

{'Task': 'Operate underwater video, sonar, recording, or related equipment to investigate underwater structures or marine life.'}, {'Task': 'Take test samples or photographs to assess the condition of Generated description:
Professionals in this role focus on maintaining and restoring access to secured areas and items. They meticulously analyze locking mechanisms, troubleshoot malfunctions, and perform necessary repairs on a variety of devices. This often involves fabricating replacement parts, adjusting intricate components, and installing new security hardware. They also provide services for emergency access situations, utilizing specialized tools and techniques to open locks without causing damage. Creating and managing key systems, including master keys, is another key responsibility. Additionally, they may install and service complex security systems and maintain detailed records of keys and lock configurations to ensure operational integrity and client satisfaction.

ONET description:
Repair and open locks, make keys, change locks and safe combinations, and install and repair safes.

Element Name: Manufactured Building and Mobile Home Installers
occupation_text:
Generated description:
These professionals are responsible for positioning and setting up manufactured buildings and mobile homes. They evaluate the condition of units, diagnose issues, and perform necessary repairs and installations. This includes tasks like sealing exterior surfaces, repairing structural damage, and replacing worn or broken components. They meticulously connect utilities, ensuring proper functioning of plumbing and electrical systems. They also troubleshoot and fix leaks in gas lines and plumbing. A key part of their role involves interpreting technical manuals and diagrams to plan work procedures, estimate costs, and determine required parts. They interact with customers to understand damage extent and explain repair needs, ensuring the units are ready for occupancy.

ONET description:
Move or install mobile homes or prefabricated buildings.

Generated description:
Individuals in this role are responsible for setting up and maintaining rigging systems to move heavy materials and equipment. They assess load requirements, select appropriate gear like cables and pulleys, and attach these to the loads using various tools. A key part of their daily work involves carefully controlling the movement of suspended objects, ensuring they navigate obstacles safely. They often direct other workers, using signals or verbal instructions, to prevent accidents and damage. Regular testing of rigging equipment is crucial for safety and reliability. After completing tasks, they dismantle and store the equipment properly. They also align and anchor machinery and prepare equipment for transportation.

ONET description:
Set up or repair rigging for construction projects, manufacturing plants, logging yards, ships and shipyards, or for the entertainment industry.

These professionals are responsible for ensuring the proper functioning of critical operational systems. They meticulously inspect electrical and mechanical components of various control and warning mechanisms, checking for defects and wear. When issues are identified, they perform repairs, which may involve tightening connections, replacing parts, lubricating moving components, or re-establishing circuitry. They also conduct routine maintenance and testing to prevent malfunctions. Their work involves diagnosing problems, utilizing a range of tools and equipment, and documenting their findings and actions. This ensures the reliable operation of interconnected systems that control movement and safety.

Install, inspect, test, maintain, or repair electric gate crossings, signals, signal equipment, track switches, section lines, or intercommunications systems within a railroad system.

Generated description:
These individuals assist skilled workers in installation, maintenance, and repair operations. Their daily activities involve fetching and supplying tools, parts, and materials needed by others, often holding items steady during assembly or repair. They also perform cleaning duties, ensuring work areas, machines, and tools are kept in order. They assist with the disassembly and reassembly of equipment, and may install or replace components and parts. This includes adjusting wiring and connections, and sometimes fabricating or welding parts based on plans. They monitor equipment operation to ensure safety and efficiency, and may help diagnose and repair malfunctions. Their role is crucial in keeping operations running smoothly and supporting the work of more experienced technicians.

ONET description:
Help installation, maintenance, and repair workers in maintenance, parts replacement, and repair of vehicles, industrial machinery, and electrical and electronic equipment. Perform duties such as furnishing tools, materials, and supplies to other workers; cleaning work area, machines, and tools; and holding materials or tools for other workers.

Generated description:
Individuals in this role are responsible for overseeing and managing the operational aspects of geothermal energy systems. They actively monitor equipment and control processes to ensure efficient power generation. This involves identifying and resolving issues through troubleshooting and repair of various components and systems. They also perform technical tasks related to the installation and testing of equipment, ensuring proper functionality. Maintaining detailed logs and documentation of all activities, including collected data and maintenance performed, is a key responsibility. Making decisions regarding equipment selection and the need for auxiliary systems to maintain operational integrity is also part of the role.

ONET description:
Perform technical activities at power plants or individual installations necessary for the generation of power from geothermal energy sources. Monitor and control operating activities at geothermal power generation facilities and perform maintenance and repairs as necessary. Install, test, and maintain residential and commercial geothermal heat pumps.

Element Name: First-Line Supervisors of Production and Operating Workers
occupation_text:
Generated description:
These individuals oversee and coordinate the work of production and operating staff. They interpret production requirements by reviewing various documents and records, then plan and assign tasks to meet established goals. Their day involves monitoring operations to ensure standards are met, inspecting materials and products for defects, and adjusting equipment as needed. They also conduct training, evaluate performance, and address employee concerns or grievances. These supervisors are responsible for enforcing safety regulations, maintaining attendance and production records, and recommending improvements to methods or efficiency. They often confer with other supervisors and management to resolve issues and ensure smooth operations, contributing to the overall production output and quality.

ONET description:
Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of production and operating workers, such as inspectors, precision workers, machine setters and operators, assemblers, fabricators, and plant and system operators. Excludes team or work leaders.

standards, budgets, production goals, and rates, based on company policies, equipment and labor availability, and workloads.'}, {'Task': 'Calculate labor and equipment requirements and production Element Name: Aircraft Structure, Surfaces, Rigging, and Systems Assemblers
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Professionals in this role meticulously assemble, fit, and fasten components for vehicles and related systems. They interpret technical documents and blueprints to accurately lay out and mark reference points for installations. Using a variety of tools and fasteners, they attach brackets, hinges, and clips, ensuring proper fit and clearance by cutting, trimming, or smoothing parts as needed. They also fabricate custom parts and clean components before assembly. After installation, they rigorously inspect and test units, systems, and assemblies for fit, alignment, performance, and defects, utilizing specialized measuring instruments. When necessary, they adjust, repair, rework, or replace components to guarantee optimal function and adherence to standards.

ONET description:
Assemble, fit, fasten, and install parts of airplanes, space vehicles, or missiles, such as tails, wings, fuselage, bulkheads, stabilizers, landing gear, rigging and control equipment, or heating and ventilating systems.

Tasks:
[{'Task': 'Assemble parts, fittings, or subassemblies on aircraft, using layout tools, hand tools, power tools, or fasteners, such as bolts, screws, rivets, or clamps.'}, {'Task': 'Read blueprints, illustrations, or specifications to determine layouts, sequences of operations, or identities or relationships of parts.'}, {'Task': 'Attach brackets, hinges, or clips to secure or support components or subassemblies, using bolts, screws, rivets, chemical bonding, or welding.'}, {'Task': 'Inspect or test installed units, parts, systems, or assemblies for fit, alignment, performance, defects, or compliance with standards, using measuring instruments or test equipment.'}, {'Task': 'Adjust, repair, rework, or replace parts or assemblies to ensure proper operation.'}, {'Task': 'Cut, trim, file, bend, or smooth parts to ensure proper fit and clearance.'}, {'Task': 'Fabricate parts needed for assembly or installation, using shop machinery or equipment.'}, {'Task': 'Layout and mark reference points and locations for installation of parts or components, using jigs, templates, or measuring and marking instruments.'}, {'Task': 'Clean, oil, or coat system components, as necessary, before assembly or attachment.'}, {'Task': 'Assemble prefabricated parts to form subassemblies.'}]

They select and load necessary materials onto specialized machinery before operating or tending it to wind wire coils. Generated description:
These professionals examine blueprints and engineering drawings to plan their work, ensuring they understand material requirements and the sequence of operations. They meticulously measure and verify that metal stock meets precise specifications before fabrication. Using a variety of tools and machinery, they cut, bend, shape, and assemble metal components according to detailed plans. They carefully position, align, and secure these parts, often using temporary measures like tack welding or specialized clamps. They also operate lifting equipment to move materials and finished units. Fabricate, position, align, and fit parts of structural metal products.

Generated description:
Individuals in this role apply layers of material onto prepared molds to create various products. They carefully mix components, saturating cloths and mats with the mixture. These saturated materials are then precisely placed onto molds, ensuring wrinkles and air bubbles are eliminated using tools or hands. They may also spray materials using specialized equipment. Reinforcing materials are bonded into place as needed. After assembly, they meticulously inspect finished items, checking for defects by visual examination, measurement, or by listening for irregularities. Excess material is trimmed to meet specifications. This process requires attention to detail and careful manipulation of materials to achieve the desired outcome.

Laminate layers of fiberglass on molds to form boat decks and hulls, bodies for golf carts, automobiles, or other products.

Generated description:
This role involves the meticulous assembly and adjustment of timing mechanisms. Daily activities include carefully examining components for defects using magnification tools, and testing subassemblies to ensure accuracy and identify issues. When problems arise, individuals disassemble the devices, diagnose the root cause, and replace or repair faulty parts. This often requires precise manipulation of small components to correct deficiencies and ensure proper function. Additionally, cleaning and lubricating parts are routine parts of the process. Maintaining strict adherence to tight tolerances is critical throughout all assembly, testing, and repair tasks to guarantee the reliable performance of the finished timing devices.

Perform precision assembling or adjusting, within narrow tolerances, of timing devices such as digital clocks or timing devices with electrical or electronic components.

They meticulously review work orders and blueprints, ensuring adherence to specifications throughout the production process. This involves performing detailed quality checks on both finished items and individual parts. In addition to hands-on assembly, they may guide work assignments, establish procedures, and train new team members. Some also contribute to decision-making processes affecting the team's operations. Element Name: Food and Tobacco Roasting, Baking, and Drying Machine Operators and Tenders
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Individuals in this role monitor and tend specialized equipment used for processing food and tobacco products. They carefully set and adjust operational controls, such as temperature and time, to meet specific processing requirements. Throughout the process, they actively observe equipment performance and product quality, making necessary adjustments based on readings from gauges and visual inspections. When processing, they read work orders to understand production needs, weigh and measure materials, and load and unload equipment. They also maintain records of production data, including quantities processed and operational parameters. Additionally, they troubleshoot minor issues, and signal colleagues to ensure smooth material flow, escalating significant problems to supervisors.

ONET description:
Operate or tend food or tobacco roasting, baking, or drying equipment, including hearth ovens, kiln driers, roasters, char kilns, and vacuum drying equipment.

Tasks:
[{'Task': 'Observe, feel, taste, or otherwise examine products during and after processing to ensure conformance to standards.'}, {'Task': 'Set temperature and time controls, light ovens, burners, driers, or roasters, and start equipment, such as conveyors, cylinders, blowers, driers, or pumps.'}, {'Task': 'Observe temperature, humidity, pressure gauges, and product samples and adjust controls, such as thermostats and valves, to maintain prescribed operating conditions for specific stages.'}, {'Task': 'Observe flow of materials and listen for machine malfunctions, such as jamming or spillage, and notify supervisors if corrective actions fail.'}, {'Task': 'Record production data, such as weight and amount of product processed, type of product, and time and temperature of processing.'}, {'Task': 'Weigh or measure products, using scale hoppers or scale conveyors.'}, {'Task': 'Operate or tend equipment that roasts, bakes, dries, or cures food items such as cocoa and coffee beans, grains, nuts, and bakery products.'}, {'Task': 'Signal coworkers to synchronize flow of materials.'}, {'Task': 'Read work orders to determine quantities and types of products to be baked, dried, or roasted.'}, {'Task': 'Fill or remove product from trays, carts, hoppers, or equipment, using scoops, peels, or shovels, or by hand.'}]

Generated description:
Individuals in this role are responsible for operating and tending equipment used to blend and mix ingredients for food products, adhering strictly to established formulas and recipes. They carefully select, measure, and weigh ingredients, controlling equipment operations by adjusting settings and monitoring gauges and thermometers to maintain specified temperatures and ensure product quality. These professionals also mix or blend ingredients, sometimes manually or by operating automated vats, and may modify operations based on sample testing to achieve desired characteristics like firmness or texture. They critically assess product samples throughout production for quality, taste, color, and texture, documenting all relevant data. Additionally, they ensure equipment and work areas are clean and sterile, provide direction to assisting workers, and report any equipment malfunctions or quality deviations.

ONET description:
Set up and operate equipment that mixes or blends ingredients used in the manufacturing of food products. Includes candy makers and cheese makers.

Element Name: Food Cooking Machine Operators and Tenders
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Individuals in this role are responsible for operating and monitoring specialized cooking equipment to prepare food products. They carefully read instructions, such as recipes and work orders, to understand specific cooking times, temperatures, and ingredient requirements. A key part of their day involves accurately measuring and loading ingredients into various machines, then precisely setting and adjusting controls for temperature, pressure, and time. They continuously observe gauges and product characteristics, making adjustments as needed to maintain quality and safety standards. This includes collecting samples for quality checks and recording production data. They also perform routine cleaning of equipment and the work area, and must be attentive to operational alarms, shutting down equipment and notifying supervisors of any malfunctions.

ONET description:
Operate or tend cooking equipment, such as steam cooking vats, deep fry cookers, pressure cookers, kettles, and boilers, to prepare food products.

[{'Task': 'Clean, wash, and sterilize equipment and cooking area, using water hoses, cleaning or sterilizing solutions, or rinses.'}, {'Task': 'Read work orders, recipes, or formulas to determine cooking times and temperatures, and ingredient specifications.'}, {'Task': 'Observe gauges, dials, and product characteristics, and adjust controls to maintain appropriate temperature, pressure, and flow of ingredients.'}, {'Task': 'Measure or weigh ingredients, using scales or measuring containers.'}, {'Task': 'Tend or operate and control equipment, such as kettles, cookers, vats and tanks, and boilers, to cook ingredients or prepare products for further processing.'}, {'Task': 'Record production and test data, such as processing steps, temperature and steam readings, cooking time, batches processed, and test results.'}, {'Task': 'Set temperature, pressure, and time controls, and start conveyers, machines, or pumps.'}, {'Task': 'Remove cooked material or products from equipment.'}, {'Task': 'Collect and examine product samples during production to test them for quality, color, content, consistency, viscosity, acidity, or specific gravity.'}, {'Task': 'Pour, dump, or load prescribed quantities of ingredients or products into cooking equipment, manually or using a hoist.'}, {'Task': 'Listen for malfunction alarms, and shut down equipment and notify supervisors when necessary.'}, {'Task': 'Notify or signal other workers to operate equipment or when processing is complete.'}, {'Task': 'Turn valves or start pumps to add ingredients or drain products from equipment and to transfer products for storage, cooling, or further processing.'}, {'Task': 'Admit required amounts of water, steam, cooking oils, or compressed air into equipment, such as by opening water valves to cool mixtures to the desired consistency.'}]

Element Name: Extruding and Drawing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Operators are responsible for preparing and running machinery that shapes materials into various forms like tubes, rods, or wires. This involves carefully setting up equipment by selecting appropriate parts and dies according to specific requirements. They then operate the machinery, controlling factors such as temperature, pressure, and speed to ensure the material is processed correctly. Operators continuously monitor the process and the resulting products, performing quality checks to identify any defects or deviations from specifications. They make necessary adjustments to controls or equipment to maintain quality and efficiency. Additionally, they may reel finished products, perform routine maintenance, and conduct minor repairs to keep the machines functioning properly.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend machines to extrude or draw thermoplastic or metal materials into tubes, rods, hoses, wire, bars, or structural shapes.

[{'Task': 'Measure and examine extruded products to locate defects and to check for conformance to specifications, adjusting controls as necessary to alter products.'}, {'Task': 'Determine setup procedures and select machine dies and parts, according to specifications.'}, {'Task': 'Start machines and set controls to regulate vacuum, air pressure, sizing rings, and temperature, and to synchronize speed of extrusion.'}, {'Task': 'Reel extruded products into rolls of specified lengths and weights.'}, {'Task': 'Install dies, machine screws, and sizing rings on machines that extrude thermoplastic or metal materials.'}, {'Task': 'Change dies on extruding machines, according to production line changes.'}, {'Task': 'Clean work areas.'}, {'Task': 'Troubleshoot, maintain, and make minor repairs to equipment.'}]

Element Name: Forging Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Workers in this role prepare and operate specialized machinery to shape metal or plastic materials. They begin by reviewing specifications, such as blueprints or work orders, to understand the required shapes and dimensions. Adjustments are made to the machinery, including installing and setting up dies, controlling pressures, and synchronizing operations to meet precise standards. Once set up, they initiate production, often starting with sample runs to verify accuracy and ensure the equipment functions correctly. Throughout the production process, they monitor the machinery and the output, making necessary adjustments to maintain quality and conform to specifications. They also conduct measurements and inspections of finished pieces. Additionally, they perform routine maintenance and minor repairs on the equipment and dies to ensure continued efficient operation.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend forging machines to taper, shape, or form metal or plastic parts.

[{'Task': 'Read work orders or blueprints to determine specified tolerances and sequences of operations for machine setup.'}, {'Task': 'Position and move metal wires or workpieces through a series of dies that compress and shape stock to form die impressions.'}, {'Task': 'Measure and inspect machined parts to ensure conformance to product specifications.'}, {'Task': 'Set up, operate, or tend presses and forging machines to perform hot or cold forging by flattening, straightening, bending, cutting, piercing, or other operations to taper, shape, or form metal.'}, {'Task': 'Turn handles or knobs to set pressures and depths of ram strokes and to synchronize machine operations.'}, {'Task': 'Install, adjust, and remove dies, synchronizing cams, forging hammers, and stop guides, using overhead cranes or other hoisting devices, and hand tools.'}, {'Task': 'Start machines to produce sample workpieces, and observe operations to detect machine malfunctions and to verify that machine setups conform to specifications.'}, {'Task': 'Confer with other workers about machine setups and operational specifications.'}, {'Task': 'Trim and compress finished forgings to specified tolerances.'}, {'Task': 'Remove dies from machines when production runs are finished.'}, {'Task': 'Repair, maintain, and replace parts on dies.'}]

Element Name: Rolling Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Individuals in this role are responsible for setting up, operating, and tending machines that form metal and plastic. They monitor machine cycles, examine raw materials and finished products, and make adjustments to correct any deviations from specifications. This involves reading production orders and blueprints to understand setup requirements and product dimensions. They manipulate controls, adjust settings for speed and distance, and ensure proper lubrication and cooling of the machinery. Additionally, they install equipment, position components, and activate associated tools for trimming. They also maintain production records and may train or direct other workers in machine operation and material handling.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend machines to roll steel or plastic forming bends, beads, knurls, rolls, or plate, or to flatten, temper, or reduce gauge of material.

Tasks:
[{'Task': 'Monitor machine cycles and mill operation to detect jamming and to ensure that products conform to specifications.'}, {'Task': 'Adjust and correct machine set-ups to reduce thicknesses, reshape products, and eliminate product defects.'}, {'Task': 'Start operation of rolling and milling machines to flatten, temper, form, and reduce sheet metal sections and to produce steel strips.'}, {'Task': 'Examine, inspect, and measure raw materials and finished products to verify conformance to specifications.'}, {'Task': 'Read rolling orders, blueprints, and mill schedules to determine setup specifications, work sequences, product dimensions, and installation procedures.'}, {'Task': 'Manipulate controls and observe dial indicators to monitor, adjust, and regulate speeds of machine mechanisms.'}, {'Task': 'Set distance points between rolls, guides, meters, and stops, according to specifications.'}, {'Task': 'Calculate draft space and roll speed for each mill stand to plan rolling sequences and specified dimensions and tempers.'}, {'Task': 'Install equipment such as guides, guards, gears, cooling equipment, and rolls, using hand tools.'}, {'Task': 'Position, align, and secure arbors, spindles, coils, mandrels, dies, and slitting knives.'}, {'Task': 'Fill oil cups, adjust valves, and observe gauges to control flow of metal coolants and lubricants onto workpieces.'}, {'Task': 'Activate shears and grinders to trim workpieces.'}, {'Task': 'Signal and assist other workers to remove and position equipment, fill hoppers, and feed materials into machines.'}, {'Task': 'Record mill production on schedule sheets.'}, {'Task': 'Direct and train other workers to change rolls, operate mill equipment, remove coils and cobbles, and band and load material.'}]

Element Name: Cutting, Punching, and Press Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Individuals in this role manage and operate machinery designed for shaping metal and plastic. They begin by reviewing work orders and production schedules to understand specific requirements, including materials, dimensions, and tolerances. Once set up, they load materials into the machines and adjust controls to establish optimal speeds and actions according to product specifications. Throughout the process, they carefully monitor the machinerys operation, recording relevant data and making necessary adjustments. After completing a production run, they meticulously inspect the workpieces for defects, measure them to ensure they meet exact specifications, and sort any flawed items. They also maintain the cleanliness of their workspace.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend machines to saw, cut, shear, slit, punch, crimp, notch, bend, or straighten metal or plastic material.

Element Name: Drilling and Boring Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Professionals in this role prepare and operate specialized machinery to shape metal and plastic components according to precise specifications. They begin by carefully studying technical documents, such as blueprints and machining instructions, to understand project requirements, including dimensions, finishes, and necessary tooling. Following this, they meticulously set up the equipment, positioning and securing workpieces using various holding devices. Operators select and install appropriate cutting tools, adjusting machine settings like speeds and feeds to ensure accurate material removal. Throughout the process, they closely monitor the operation, making adjustments as needed and using measuring instruments to verify that the work meets exact standards. They also perform routine maintenance, such as changing or sharpening tools, and troubleshoot any issues that arise to maintain production quality and efficiency.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend drilling machines to drill, bore, ream, mill, or countersink metal or plastic work pieces.

Tasks:
[{'Task': 'Verify conformance of machined work to specifications, using measuring instruments, such as calipers, micrometers, or fixed or telescoping gauges.'}, {'Task': 'Study machining instructions, job orders, or blueprints to determine dimensional or finish specifications, sequences of operations, setups, or tooling requirements.'}, {'Task': 'Move machine controls to lower tools to workpieces and to engage automatic feeds.'}, {'Task': 'Verify that workpiece reference lines are parallel to the axis of table rotation, using dial indicators mounted in spindles.'}, {'Task': 'Establish zero reference points on workpieces, such as at the intersections of two edges or over hole locations.'}, {'Task': 'Change worn cutting tools, using wrenches.'}, {'Task': 'Select and set cutting speeds, feed rates, depths of cuts, and cutting tools, according to machining instructions or knowledge of metal properties.'}, {'Task': 'Position and secure workpieces on tables, using bolts, jigs, clamps, shims, or other holding devices.'}, {'Task': 'Observe drilling or boring machine operations to detect any problems.'}, {'Task': 'Lift workpieces onto work tables either manually or with hoists or direct crane operators to lift and position workpieces.'}, {'Task': 'Turn valves and direct flow of coolants or cutting oil over cutting areas.'}, {'Task': 'Install tools in spindles.'}, {'Task': 'Perform minor assembly, such as fastening parts with nuts, bolts, or screws, using power tools or hand tools.'}, {'Task': 'Operate single- or multiple-spindle drill presses to bore holes so that machining operations can be performed on metal or plastic workpieces.'}, {'Task': 'Lay out reference lines and machining locations on work, using layout tools, and applying knowledge of shop math and layout techniques.'}, {'Task': 'Sharpen cutting tools, using bench grinders.'}]

Element Name: Grinding, Lapping, Polishing, and Buffing Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
occupation_text:
Generated description:
These professionals prepare and operate specialized machinery to refine metal and plastic components. They meticulously review production orders and blueprints to understand specifications and plan the sequence of operations. Setting up the equipment involves selecting and mounting appropriate tooling, and positioning workpieces securely. Operators then initiate the machinery, carefully monitoring its performance for any irregularities. They make precise adjustments to controls and settings to ensure the desired outcome, often applying cooling or lubricating agents. Throughout the process, they regularly inspect workpieces using various measuring tools to confirm they meet strict quality standards. When issues arise, they troubleshoot, make minor repairs, or alert supervisors for further assistance.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend grinding and related tools that remove excess material or burrs from surfaces, sharpen edges or corners, or buff, hone, or polish metal or plastic work pieces.

They regularly measure and inspect workpieces throughout the process, using precision instruments to verify conformance to specifications and identify any defects. This role also includes troubleshooting malfunctions, performing routine maintenance to keep equipment in working order, and collaborating with others to resolve technical issues or optimize procedures. They must also manage materials and waste responsibly.

Generated description:
Professionals in this role are responsible for operating and tending various types of furnaces used to melt and refine metals. They carefully regulate fuel and air supplies, or control electrical currents and coolant flow, to maintain precise temperatures. By observing gauges and the color of molten materials, they make adjustments to ensure specifications are met. They weigh and charge materials into furnaces, and operate controls to discharge metal. These individuals also draw samples for analysis and record production data. Additionally, they perform inspections of furnaces and equipment to identify potential defects or wear, ensuring smooth and efficient operations throughout the production process.

ONET description:
Operate or tend furnaces, such as gas, oil, coal, electric-arc or electric induction, open-hearth, or oxygen furnaces, to melt and refine metal before casting or to produce specified types of steel.

Generated description:
Individuals in this role carefully manage molten materials, meticulously regulating their flow into prepared forms to create ingots and other cast items. They closely monitor heating processes, observing temperature indicators and material appearance to ensure specifications are met, making necessary adjustments to melting equipment. Accurate sampling and positioning of equipment are key, contributing to the quality and integrity of the final cast components. Careful handling and transport of materials are also part of the daily workflow.

This involves cutting, shaping, forming, drilling, and finishing components to exact specifications. They may program automated equipment for intricate fabrication tasks. Collaboration with engineering colleagues is essential to discuss challenges, resolve developmental issues, and suggest product improvements, while maintaining detailed records of processes and dimensions.

Generated description:
Workers in this role focus on constructing precise molds and cores essential for metal casting. They meticulously prepare materials, often by sifting and packing sand into intricate contours using various tools. This involves carefully positioning patterns and reinforcing components within mold sections, ensuring everything aligns correctly before assembly. A key part of their work includes applying parting agents to facilitate the smooth removal of patterns. They also perform necessary repairs and cleaning on mold surfaces, and cut specific openings for pouring. Throughout the process, they utilize lifting equipment and coordinate with others to manage the movement of heavy components, ensuring the integrity and accuracy of the final mold or core.

ONET description:
Make or form wax or sand cores or molds used in the production of metal castings in foundries.

[{'Task': 'Clean and smooth molds, cores, and core boxes, and repair surface imperfections.'}, {'Task': 'Sift and pack sand into mold sections, core boxes, and pattern contours, using hand or pneumatic ramming tools.'}, {'Task': 'Position patterns inside mold sections, and clamp sections together.'}, {'Task': 'Position cores into lower sections of molds, and reassemble molds for pouring.'}, {'Task': 'Sprinkle or spray parting agents onto patterns and mold sections to facilitate removal of patterns from molds.'}, {'Task': 'Form and assemble slab cores around patterns, and position wire in mold sections to reinforce molds, using hand tools and glue.'}, {'Task': 'Move and position workpieces, such as mold sections, patterns, and bottom boards, using cranes, or signal others to move workpieces.'}, {'Task': 'Lift upper mold sections from lower sections, and remove molded patterns.'}, {'Task': 'Cut spouts, runner holes, and sprue holes into molds.'}]

Element Name: Molding, Coremaking, and Casting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Individuals in this role are responsible for setting up and operating specialized machinery used in the production of molded and cast items. They meticulously follow specifications, blueprints, and work orders to configure machines, adjusting settings like pressure, temperature, and feed rates to meet precise requirements. Throughout the production process, they continuously monitor machine operations and output, observing meters and gauges to ensure products conform to quality standards. When issues arise, such as jams or malfunctions, they make necessary adjustments or troubleshoot problems. This involves inspecting finished parts for defects, cleaning and maintaining equipment, and preparing machines for subsequent production runs by removing components and preparing molds.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend metal or plastic molding, casting, or coremaking machines to mold or cast metal or thermoplastic parts or products.

Tasks:
[{'Task': 'Measure and visually inspect products for surface and dimension defects to ensure conformance to specifications, using precision measuring instruments.'}, {'Task': 'Observe continuous operation of automatic machines to ensure that products meet specifications and to detect jams or malfunctions, making adjustments as necessary.'}, {'Task': 'Set up, operate, or tend metal or plastic molding, casting, or coremaking machines to mold or cast metal or thermoplastic parts or products.'}, {'Task': 'Turn valves and dials of machines to regulate pressure, temperature, and speed and feed rates, and to set cycle times.'}, {'Task': 'Read specifications, blueprints, and work orders to determine setups, temperatures, and time settings required to mold, form, or cast plastic materials, as well as to plan production sequences.'}, {'Task': 'Observe meters and gauges to verify and record temperatures, pressures, and press-cycle times.'}, {'Task': 'Connect water hoses to cooling systems of dies, using hand tools.'}, {'Task': 'Remove parts, such as dies, from machines after production runs are finished.'}, {'Task': 'Perform maintenance work such as cleaning and oiling machines.'}, {'Task': 'Smooth and clean inner surfaces of molds, using brushes, scrapers, air hoses, or grinding wheels, and fill imperfections with refractory material.'}]

Element Name: Multiple Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
occupation_text:
Generated description:
These professionals meticulously prepare and operate various machines to shape metal and plastic components. They interpret blueprints and job orders to understand product specifications and plan the sequence of operations. Key responsibilities include selecting, installing, and adjusting machine components like cutters and guides, and positioning stock materials. Operators continuously monitor machine functions and workpiece quality, making adjustments as needed to ensure accuracy and prevent defects. They perform routine maintenance, such as cleaning and lubricating equipment, and make minor repairs. When necessary, they also instruct other workers and maintain detailed operational records.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend more than one type of cutting or forming machine tool or robot.

Generated description:
Individuals in this role analyze technical specifications and blueprints to plan the fabrication of tools, dies, and fixtures. They meticulously measure, mark, and scribe metal or plastic stock, then set up and operate various machine tools to precisely cut, shape, and form components. After fabricating parts, they carefully inspect them for accuracy and defects, using a range of measuring instruments. These professionals fit and assemble components, often using hand tools or welding, to create functional tools, dies, jigs, or gauges. They conduct test runs to ensure everything meets exact specifications, making necessary adjustments. They also select appropriate materials based on required properties and maintain equipment.

ONET description:
Analyze specifications, lay out metal stock, set up and operate machine tools, and fit and assemble parts to make and repair dies, cutting tools, jigs, fixtures, gauges, and machinists' hand tools.

Generated description:

They meticulously align and secure workpieces using various tools and equipment. Applying specialized knowledge, they select appropriate welding, soldering, or brazing methods and equipment to join or repair metal parts. Throughout the process, they monitor operations closely to prevent overheating, warping, or distortion, making adjustments as needed. After joining, they refine the work by removing excess material and checking for defects, ensuring the final product meets precise specifications. Safety is a constant priority, involving the use of protective gear and adherence to safe work practices.

ONET description:
Use hand-welding, flame-cutting, hand-soldering, or brazing equipment to weld or join metal components or to fill holes, indentations, or seams of fabricated metal products.

Element Name: Welding, Soldering, and Brazing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Individuals in this role are responsible for setting up and operating machinery designed for welding, soldering, or brazing operations. They meticulously prepare metal surfaces and components, ensuring precise alignment and secure positioning for bonding processes. This involves interpreting technical documents, selecting appropriate materials and tools, and making precise adjustments to machine controls and settings. Operators monitor equipment performance using various instruments, conduct trial runs, and make necessary corrections to maintain adherence to specifications. They also perform routine maintenance and troubleshooting to ensure efficient operation and may guide the work of others. Finally, they inspect finished products to verify quality and record operational data.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend welding, soldering, or brazing machines or robots that weld, braze, solder, or heat treat metal products, components, or assemblies. Includes workers who operate laser cutters or laser-beam machines.

Element Name: Heat Treating Equipment Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Individuals in this role are responsible for operating and tending specialized equipment used for treating metal and plastic objects. They carefully review production schedules and work orders to understand specific processing requirements, including temperatures and heating durations. Key responsibilities involve setting up the equipment, adjusting controls to maintain precise temperatures and heating times, and monitoring various indicators to ensure adherence to specifications. They initiate the heating process by loading materials or signaling for assistance, and carefully track the duration of treatment. After processing, they remove items and manage cooling processes. They also maintain operational records and may instruct new team members on equipment operation and procedures.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend heating equipment, such as heat-treating furnaces, flame-hardening machines, induction machines, soaking pits, or vacuum equipment to temper, harden, anneal, or heat treat metal or plastic objects.

[{'Task': 'Read production schedules and work orders to determine processing sequences, furnace temperatures, and heat cycle requirements for objects to be heat-treated.'}, {'Task': 'Record times that parts are removed from furnaces to document that objects have attained specified temperatures for specified times.'}, {'Task': 'Adjust controls to maintain temperatures and heating times, using thermal instruments and charts, dials and gauges of furnaces, and color of stock in furnaces to make setting determinations.'}, {'Task': 'Start conveyors and open furnace doors to load stock, or signal crane operators to uncover soaking pits and lower ingots into them.'}, {'Task': 'Set up and operate or tend machines, such as furnaces, baths, flame-hardening machines, and electronic induction machines, that harden, anneal, and heat-treat metal.'}, {'Task': 'Remove parts from furnaces after specified times, and air dry or cool parts in water, oil brine, or other baths.'}, {'Task': 'Move controls to light gas burners and to adjust gas and water flow and flame temperature.'}, {'Task': 'Instruct new workers in machine operation.'}]

Element Name: Plating Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
occupation_text:
Generated description:
These professionals are responsible for operating and tending specialized machinery used in coating metal and plastic items. Their daily activities involve carefully immersing workpieces into various solutions or molten metals for specific durations. They meticulously monitor gauges and control operational settings, making necessary adjustments to voltage and current to maintain precise coating processes. A key part of their role includes inspecting finished products for any imperfections, such as uneven coverage or defects, and verifying that specifications are met. They also perform quality checks by measuring the thickness of applied coatings. Additionally, they manage the cleaning and drying of coated items and maintain accurate production records, troubleshooting issues as they arise to ensure quality standards.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend plating machines to coat metal or plastic products with chromium, zinc, copper, cadmium, nickel, or other metal to protect or decorate surfaces. Typically, the product being coated is immersed in molten metal or an electrolytic solution.

Tasks:
[{'Task': 'Immerse workpieces in coating solutions or liquid metal or plastic for specified times.'}, {'Task': 'Adjust dials to regulate flow of current and voltage supplied to terminals to control plating processes.'}, {'Task': 'Inspect coated or plated areas for defects, such as air bubbles or uneven coverage.'}, {'Task': 'Set up, operate, or tend plating or coating machines to coat metal or plastic products with chromium, zinc, copper, cadmium, nickel, or other metal to protect or decorate surfaces.'}, {'Task': 'Observe gauges to ensure that machines are operating properly, making adjustments or stopping machines when problems occur.'}, {'Task': 'Remove objects from solutions at periodic intervals and observe objects to verify conformance to specifications.'}, {'Task': 'Maintain production records.'}, {'Task': 'Remove excess materials or impurities from objects, using air hoses or grinding machines.'}, {'Task': 'Examine completed objects to determine thicknesses of metal deposits, or measure thicknesses by using instruments such as micrometers.'}, {'Task': 'Rinse coated objects in cleansing liquids and dry them with cloths, centrifugal driers, or by tumbling in sawdust-filled barrels.'}]

Generated description:
Professionals in this role meticulously refine metal objects through grinding, polishing, and smoothing processes. They carefully analyze blueprints and specifications to determine the optimal procedures and machine setups, selecting and mounting appropriate tools and abrasive materials. During operations, they continuously monitor equipment and workpieces, making necessary adjustments to ensure precise dimensions and surface quality. This involves inspecting, measuring, and feeling the metal, and adjusting cutting tools as needed. They also manage coolant flow and perform routine maintenance and minor repairs on machinery. Their work concludes with inspecting finished pieces for defects and preparing them for the next stage, all while adhering to strict quality standards.

ONET description:
Perform precision smoothing, sharpening, polishing, or grinding of metal objects.

Generated description:
This role involves preparing digital and physical content for the printing process. Professionals in this occupation meticulously review and proofread text and images, ensuring accuracy and quality control. They use specialized equipment and software to format pages, arrange text and graphics, and make necessary adjustments to size and layout. A key responsibility is ensuring all necessary digital files, including fonts and graphics, are complete and correctly formatted for the production stage. Some may operate and maintain equipment that converts digital data directly into printing plates. They also manage and retrieve digital information, and perform routine maintenance and minor repairs on their equipment to ensure smooth operations.

ONET description:
Format and proof text and images submitted by designers and clients into finished pages that can be printed. Includes digital and photo typesetting. May produce printing plates.

Generated description:
These professionals are responsible for operating and maintaining various types of printing machinery. They begin by reviewing job orders to understand specifications like quantity, stock, and color. Then, they prepare the equipment by loading materials, securing components, and inputting digital settings. Throughout the printing process, they closely monitor automated systems and inspect samples to ensure quality and alignment, making adjustments to ink flow, feed controls, and other parameters as needed. They also perform routine maintenance, cleaning, and minor repairs to keep the equipment in good working order. Record-keeping and supply management are also part of their daily duties, ensuring smooth and efficient production.

ONET description:
Set up and operate digital, letterpress, lithographic, flexographic, gravure, or other printing machines. Includes short-run offset printing presses.

[{'Task': 'Start presses and pull proofs to check for ink coverage and density, alignment, and registration.'}, {'Task': 'Examine job orders to determine quantities to be printed, stock specifications, colors, or special printing instructions.'}, {'Task': 'Adjust ink fountain flow rates.'}, {'Task': 'Verify that paper and ink meet the specifications for a given job.'}, {'Task': 'Collect and inspect random samples during print runs to identify any necessary adjustments.'}, {'Task': 'Feed paper through press cylinders and adjust feed and tension controls.'}, {'Task': 'Monitor automated press operation systems and respond to fault, error, or alert messages.'}, {'Task': 'Load presses with paper and make necessary adjustments, according to paper size.'}, {'Task': 'Secure printing plates to printing units and adjust tolerances.'}, {'Task': 'Clean ink fountains, plates, or printing unit cylinders when press runs are completed.'}, {'Task': 'Change press plates, blankets, or cylinders, as required.'}, {'Task': 'Obtain or mix inks and fill ink fountains.'}, {'Task': 'Input production job settings into workstation terminals that control automated printing systems.'}, {'Task': 'Clean or oil presses or make minor repairs, using hand tools.'}, {'Task': 'Maintain time or production records.'}, {'Task': 'Monitor inventory levels on a regular basis, ordering or requesting additional supplies, as necessary.'}, {'Task': 'Monitor environmental factors, such as humidity and temperature, that may impact equipment performance and make necessary adjustments.'}]

Generated description:
Individuals in this role meticulously examine stitched, collated, or unbound materials, looking for defects like torn pages or imperfect bindings. They interpret work orders to precisely set up and adjust machinery, ensuring proper calibration for size and specifications. This involves installing and fine-tuning various machine components, then operating equipment to perform tasks such as trimming edges, stitching, or applying adhesives. Continuous monitoring of machine operations is crucial to detect malfunctions or identify the need for adjustments, while also performing routine cleaning, lubrication, and minor repairs to maintain operational efficiency. They may also be responsible for training new personnel and documenting daily production records.

ONET description:
Bind books and other publications or finish printed products by hand or machine. May set up binding and finishing machines.

Generated description:
Individuals in this role are responsible for processing a variety of textile articles. They meticulously examine and sort items based on factors like color, fabric type, and the level of cleaning needed. They operate and monitor specialized machinery, carefully regulating the use of cleaning agents and water. After the cleaning cycle, they remove articles, sort and count them, and then prepare them for return by folding, wrapping, or hanging. This work also involves routine maintenance, such as cleaning filters and lubricating equipment, to ensure the machinery functions correctly. Receiving and identifying articles, often by marking them with codes or names, is also a key part of the daily workflow.

ONET description:
Operate or tend washing or dry-cleaning machines to wash or dry-clean industrial or household articles, such as cloth garments, suede, leather, furs, blankets, draperies, linens, rugs, and carpets. Includes spotters and dyers of these articles.

Element Name: Pressers, Textile, Garment, and Related Materials
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Individuals in this role focus on shaping and finishing articles by operating various pressing machines and hand tools. They carefully position materials onto machinery or work surfaces, selecting the appropriate equipment and settings based on material properties, temperature tolerance, and required pressure. Tasks involve operating controls to regulate machine functions, applying steam or moisture to soften fibers, and manipulating materials to remove wrinkles, shape components, or achieve specific forms. They also perform finishing touches on delicate items, correct imperfections, and ensure articles meet specified measurements and quality standards. Responsibilities extend to cleaning and maintaining equipment and preparing finished articles for subsequent stages or distribution.

ONET description:
Press or shape articles by hand or machine.

Tasks:
[{'Task': 'Hang, fold, package, and tag finished articles for delivery to customers.'}, {'Task': 'Operate steam, hydraulic, or other pressing machines to remove wrinkles from garments and flatwork items, or to shape, form, or patch articles.'}, {'Task': 'Straighten, smooth, or shape materials to prepare them for pressing.'}, {'Task': 'Remove finished pieces from pressing machines and hang or stack them for cooling, or forward them for additional processing.'}, {'Task': 'Finish pleated garments, determining sizes of pleats from evidence of old pleats or from work orders, using machine presses or hand irons.'}, {'Task': 'Lower irons, rams, or pressing heads of machines into position over material to be pressed.'}, {'Task': 'Identify and treat spots on garments.'}, {'Task': 'Shrink, stretch, or block articles by hand to conform to original measurements, using forms, blocks, and steam.'}, {'Task': 'Finish fancy garments such as evening gowns and costumes, using hand irons to produce high quality finishes.'}, {'Task': 'Push and pull irons over surfaces of articles to smooth or shape them.'}, {'Task': 'Finish pants, jackets, shirts, skirts and other dry-cleaned and laundered articles, using hand irons.'}, {'Task': 'Slide material back and forth over heated, metal, ball-shaped forms to smooth and press portions of garments that cannot be satisfactorily pressed with flat pressers or hand irons.'}, {'Task': 'Select appropriate pressing machines, based on garment properties such as heat tolerance.'}, {'Task': 'Spray water over fabric to soften fibers when not using steam irons.'}, {'Task': 'Position materials such as cloth garments, felt, or straw on tables, dies, or feeding mechanisms of pressing machines, or on ironing boards or work tables.'}, {'Task': 'Moisten materials to soften and smooth them.'}, {'Task': 'Clean and maintain pressing machines, using cleaning solutions and lubricants.'}, {'Task': 'Press ties on small pressing machines.'}, {'Task': 'Block or shape knitted garments after cleaning.'}, {'Task': 'Activate and adjust machine controls to regulate temperature and pressure of rollers, ironing shoes, or plates, according to Element Name: Shoe and Leather Workers and Repairers
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Individuals in this role meticulously work with leather and similar materials to create, adorn, or mend various items. They begin by carefully examining articles for damage or wear, then remove defective sections. Following patterns or outlines, they precisely cut materials using specialized tools. They then assemble components by aligning, stitching, gluing, or riveting them together. This often involves using sewing machines or hand tools to join fabrics, leather, or other substances. Finally, they may perform decorative or finishing processes like dyeing, polishing, stamping, or engraving to achieve the desired aesthetic. They also install hardware, such as buckles or rings, and conduct final inspections to ensure quality.

Element Name: Textile Bleaching and Dyeing Machine Operators and Tenders
occupation_text:
Generated description:
These professionals operate and tend machinery used in textile processing. They carefully monitor equipment, observing screens and controls to ensure correct operation and specified conditions like temperature and flow rates. When necessary, they adjust controls to maintain optimal settings and add necessary substances to processing tanks according to formulas and test results. They also perform checks on materials, examining and feeling them to identify defects or deviations from standards. These individuals collaborate with colleagues to understand order details and processing plans, and they are responsible for identifying and reporting equipment malfunctions or needed repairs to supervisors or mechanics. They also conduct routine inspections of machinery.

ONET description:
Operate or tend machines to bleach, shrink, wash, dye, or finish textiles or synthetic or glass fibers.

[{'Task': 'Weigh ingredients, such as dye, to be mixed together for use in textile processing.'}, {'Task': 'Start and control machines and equipment to wash, bleach, dye, or otherwise process and finish fabric, yarn, thread, or other textile goods.'}, {'Task': 'Observe display screens, control panels, equipment, and cloth entering or exiting processes to determine if equipment is operating correctly.'}, {'Task': 'Notify supervisors or mechanics of equipment malfunctions.'}, {'Task': 'Monitor factors such as temperatures and dye flow rates to ensure that they are within specified ranges.'}, {'Task': 'Add dyes, water, detergents, or chemicals to tanks to dilute or strengthen solutions, according to established formulas and solution test results.'}, {'Task': 'Examine and feel products to identify defects and variations from coloring and other processing standards.'}, {'Task': 'Adjust equipment controls to maintain specified heat, tension, and speed.'}, {'Task': 'Soak specified textile products for designated times.'}, {'Task': 'Inspect machinery to determine necessary adjustments and repairs.'}, {'Task': 'Confer with coworkers to get information about order details, processing plans, or problems that occur.'}]

They perform routine maintenance, including cleaning and lubricating equipment, and also conduct inspections to identify and address any potential malfunctions or worn parts, making repairs as needed. Element Name: Textile Knitting and Weaving Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Operators meticulously set up and tend machines used in textile production. They begin by threading yarn and fabric through intricate machine components. Throughout the production cycle, they continuously monitor machine operations, observing the output for any defects or deviations from specifications. Operators make necessary adjustments to ensure quality and efficiency, and stop machines once the required quantity is reached. When malfunctions occur, they diagnose issues, perform minor repairs, or call for specialized assistance. They also confer with colleagues to exchange information regarding production orders, processes, or any encountered problems. Periodic inspections of machinery are conducted to identify potential repair needs and ensure optimal performance.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend machines that knit, loop, weave, or draw in textiles.

Element Name: Textile Winding, Twisting, and Drawing Out Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
occupation_text:
Generated description:
These professionals operate and oversee machinery that processes raw fibers into yarn or thread. They prepare machines by threading materials and setting up components, then monitor their performance, ensuring smooth and continuous operation. Key responsibilities include observing for any defects, malfunctions, or material shortages, and making necessary adjustments to maintain product quality and quantity. They also replace exhausted supplies and meticulously record production details. Regular inspection of equipment helps identify potential repair needs, and test runs are conducted to verify settings and confirm product specifications are met. Communication with supervisors regarding any mechanical issues is also a crucial part of their daily activities.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend machines that wind or twist textiles; or draw out and combine sliver, such as wool, hemp, or synthetic fibers. Includes slubber machine and drawing frame operators.

Element Name: Extruding and Forming Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Synthetic and Glass Fibers
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Operators monitor and control specialized machinery used to produce continuous filaments from various synthetic materials. They are responsible for setting up the equipment, loading raw materials, and initiating the operational process. Throughout the production cycle, they closely observe control panels and gauges to ensure smooth functioning and detect any anomalies, such as blockages or defects. Operators actively adjust machine settings and feed rates to maintain optimal performance. They must promptly respond to malfunctions, stopping machines as needed and informing colleagues about issues. This role also involves routine cleaning and maintenance of the machinery to prevent breakdowns and ensure product quality. Accurate record-keeping of any operational problems is also a key responsibility.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend machines that extrude and form continuous filaments from synthetic materials, such as liquid polymer, rayon, and fiberglass.

[{'Task': 'Set up, operate, or tend machines that extrude and form filaments from synthetic materials such as rayon, fiberglass, or liquid polymers.'}, {'Task': 'Press buttons to stop machines when processes are complete or when malfunctions are detected.'}, {'Task': 'Notify other workers of defects, and direct them to adjust extruding and forming machines.'}, {'Task': 'Observe machine operations, control boards, and gauges to detect malfunctions such as clogged bushings and defective binder applicators.'}, {'Task': 'Load materials into extruding and forming machines, using hand tools, and adjust feed mechanisms to set feed rates.'}, {'Task': 'Move controls to activate and adjust extruding and forming machines.'}, {'Task': 'Record details of machine malfunctions.'}, {'Task': 'Clean and maintain extruding and forming machines, using hand tools.'}]

Generated description:
Individuals in this role translate design concepts into precise, scalable patterns. They examine sketches and specifications to determine pattern parts and material requirements, often consulting with designers. Using drafting tools or computer systems, they draw or adapt patterns, calculating dimensions for various sizes and accounting for material stretch. They create master patterns for production, and may also draw details like pleats or buttonholes. After testing patterns with sample garments and making adjustments based on fittings, they finalize patterns, marking them with essential information. Some also cut fabric or master patterns directly, or input specifications for automated cutting. A key responsibility involves optimizing pattern layout to minimize material waste.

ONET description:
Draw and construct sets of precision master fabric patterns or layouts. May also mark and cut fabrics and apparel.

Generated description:
Individuals in this occupation assess furniture and existing coverings to identify needed repairs or replacements. They remove old materials, examine underlying structures for defects, and make necessary adjustments to padding, springs, or webbing. Using measuring instruments and patterns, they cut new fabric according to design specifications and work orders. These professionals then build up surfaces with padding materials and carefully attach the new covering, securing it with hand tools and fasteners. They also repair furniture frames and refinish exposed wood. Throughout the process, they make decisions about material selection and application methods to ensure quality results and create custom or restored upholstered items.

Make, repair, or replace upholstery for household furniture or transportation vehicles.

Generated description:
Individuals in this role plan and execute the construction and repair of wooden articles, establishing specifications based on blueprints, drawings, or oral instructions. They meticulously measure and mark dimensions on materials before cutting and shaping them using various machines or hand tools to meet precise specifications.  A key part of the day involves assembling components, ensuring tight fits and quality through gluing, fastening, and reinforcing joints.  They also focus on preparing surfaces through sanding and trimming, and may install hardware.  Continuous monitoring of operations and adherence to quality control standards are essential for producing finished wooden products that meet or exceed requirements. They often troubleshoot and repair existing items.

ONET description:
Cut, shape, and assemble wooden articles or set up and operate a variety of woodworking machines, such as power saws, jointers, and mortisers to surface, cut, or shape lumber or to fabricate parts for wood products.

Generated description:
Individuals in this role prepare and apply finishes to items, often made of wood. They meticulously examine pieces to assess damage and determine appropriate restoration or finishing methods. This involves cleaning surfaces, smoothing imperfections, and repairing structural damage using various tools and materials. They carefully remove old finishes and worn parts, then meticulously prepare surfaces by sanding or shaping them. Selecting and mixing appropriate finishing substances, they apply them evenly through brushing, spraying, or rubbing to achieve the desired color, shade, and texture. This may include stenciling, gilding, or distressing surfaces to achieve specific aesthetic effects. They also mask parts to protect them from finishing substances and reassemble items once the finishing process is complete.

ONET description:
Shape, finish, and refinish damaged, worn, or used furniture or new high-grade furniture to specified color or finish.

Tasks:
[{'Task': 'Brush, spray, or hand-rub finishing ingredients, such as paint, oil, stain, or wax, onto and into wood grain and apply lacquer or other sealers.'}, {'Task': 'Fill and smooth cracks or depressions, remove marks and imperfections, and repair broken parts, using plastic or wood putty, glue, nails, or screws.'}, {'Task': 'Smooth, shape, and touch up surfaces to prepare them for finishing, using sandpaper, pumice stones, steel wool, chisels, sanders, or grinders.'}, {'Task': 'Remove accessories prior to finishing, and mask areas that should not be exposed to finishing processes or substances.'}, {'Task': 'Remove old finishes and damaged or deteriorated parts, using hand tools, stripping tools, sandpaper, steel wool, abrasives, solvents, or dip baths.'}, {'Task': 'Treat warped or stained surfaces to restore original contours and colors.'}, {'Task': 'Select appropriate finishing ingredients such as paint, stain, lacquer, shellac, or varnish, depending on factors such as wood hardness and surface type.'}, {'Task': 'Mix finish ingredients to obtain desired colors or shades.'}, {'Task': 'Remove excess solvent, using cloths soaked in paint thinner.'}, {'Task': 'Examine furniture to determine the extent of damage or deterioration, and to decide on the best method for repair or restoration.'}, {'Task': 'Distress surfaces with woodworking tools or abrasives before staining to create an antique appearance, or rub surfaces to bring out highlights and shadings.'}, {'Task': 'Stencil, gild, emboss, mark, or paint designs or borders to reproduce the original appearance of restored pieces, or to decorate new pieces.'}, {'Task': 'Disassemble items to prepare them for finishing, using hand tools.'}]

Generated description:
Individuals in this role interpret blueprints, drawings, and specifications to construct full-size and scale models. They meticulously select wooden stock, lay out precise measurements, and mark patterns for fabrication. Utilizing a range of tools and machinery, they cut, shape, trim, and smooth wood to achieve specified dimensions and contours. Parts are then fitted, fastened, and assembled using various materials and techniques to create patterns, templates, or complete models. They verify dimensions throughout the process and ensure finished pieces are accurately identified for assembly. Additionally, they may build jigs to aid in assembly and maintain records for future reference.

ONET description:
Construct full-size and scale wooden precision models of products. Includes wood jig builders and loft workers.

Generated description:
Individuals in this role meticulously interpret blueprints and specifications to plan and construct detailed wooden models. They precisely lay out and mark dimensions on wood stock using various measuring tools. Utilizing hand tools and woodworking machinery, they cut, shape, trim, and assemble wooden components to form patterns, ensuring accurate dimensions and smooth surfaces. Plan, lay out, and construct wooden unit or sectional patterns used in forming sand molds for castings.

Element Name: Sawing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Wood
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Individuals in this role are responsible for operating and tending wood sawing machinery to precisely cut and shape materials. This involves setting up equipment, including mounting and adjusting blades, and monitoring operations to ensure accuracy and proper functioning. They meticulously inspect workpieces, using measuring tools to verify dimensions and mark cuts. Troubleshooting and resolving machine issues, such as clearing jams or replacing worn components, are crucial parts of the daily routine. Maintaining machines through lubrication and cleaning is also essential for efficient and safe operation. These duties require careful attention to detail, adherence to specifications, and the ability to manage equipment effectively throughout the production process.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend wood sawing machines. May operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment. Includes lead sawyers.

Tasks:
[{'Task': 'Inspect and measure workpieces to mark for cuts and to verify the accuracy of cuts, using rulers, squares, or caliper rules.'}, {'Task': 'Adjust saw blades, using wrenches and rulers, or by turning handwheels or pressing pedals, levers, or panel buttons.'}, {'Task': 'Mount and bolt sawing blades or attachments to machine shafts.'}, {'Task': 'Set up, operate, or tend saws or machines that cut or trim wood to specified dimensions, such as circular saws, band saws, multiple-blade sawing machines, scroll saws, ripsaws, or crozer machines.'}, {'Task': 'Inspect stock for imperfections or to estimate grades or qualities of stock or workpieces.'}, {'Task': 'Monitor sawing machines, adjusting speed and tension and clearing jams to ensure proper operation.'}, {'Task': 'Sharpen blades, or replace defective or worn blades or bands, using hand tools.'}, {'Task': 'Guide workpieces against saws, saw over workpieces by hand, or operate automatic feeding devices to guide cuts.'}, {'Task': 'Clear machine jams, using hand tools.'}, {'Task': 'Lubricate or clean machines, using wrenches, grease guns, or solvents.'}]

Element Name: Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Except Sawing
occupation_text:
Generated description:
Individuals in this role are responsible for operating and tending various woodworking machines. They begin by reviewing specifications and preparing materials and machine setups. This involves installing and adjusting necessary components, setting controls, and ensuring all parts are functioning correctly and safely. Throughout the process, they monitor machine operations, examining raw materials for defects and finished workpieces for accuracy against specifications using various measuring tools and visual inspection. Adjustments are made to controls, settings, and machine components as needed to maintain quality and efficiency. They also perform routine maintenance, such as cleaning and lubricating machines, and replace worn parts or tools to ensure optimal performance and product quality.

ONET description:
Set up, operate, or tend woodworking machines, such as drill presses, lathes, shapers, routers, sanders, planers, and wood nailing machines. May operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment.

[{'Task': 'Set up, program, operate, or tend computerized or manual woodworking machines, such as drill presses, lathes, shapers, routers, sanders, planers, or wood-nailing machines.'}, {'Task':
